items.question: Is Fargo a True Story?
items.answer: Contrary to the claim that appears at the beginning of each episode and similar to the movie Fargo (1996), the story is completely fictional.

items.question: What Is Fargo and How Is It Linked to the Series?
items.answer: Fargo is the largest city of North Dakota in the United States. It's only shown in the series in the seventh episode in Season One..

items.question: Where was Fargo filmed?
items.answer: The series was filmed in Calgary, Alberta in Canada.

items.question: Season 1: In episode six, where did the fish come from?
items.answer: The rain of fish in episode six is a probably due to a water spout picking up fish from Lake Superior, which freezes 1 in 20 years according to Wikipedia.Read more here:http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raining_animalshttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_SuperiorWriter perspective: In the beginning of episode seven, Chaz, Kitty and Gordo are in the kitchen when the reporter in the TV News refers to a possible tornado causing the incident.

items.question: Is Season 2 a prequel to Season 1?
items.answer: Somewhat, Season One took place in 2006 in Bemidji, Minnesota, which is in the northern part of the state. Season Two is in 1979 in Luverne, Minnesota, which is in the Southwest corner of the State. One recurring character is Lou Solverson, portrayed by Keith Carradine for Season One who is a retired cop turned diner manager. Season Two has Patrick Wilson playing a younger Lou Solverson who is part of the state highway patrol.

items.question: Where exactly does the show take place per season and when?
items.answer: Each season we will see a glimpe of Fargo, North Dakota.Season One: Bemidji and Duluth, Minnesota, 2006-2007Season Two: Luverne, Minnesota, Fargo, North Dakota and Sioux Falls, South Dakota, 1979Season Three: Eden Valley, Eden Prairie, and St. Cloud, Minnesota, 2010-2011Season Four: Kansas City, Missouri and Liberal, Kansas, 1950-1951

items.question: Where can I find a song I heard during the show?
items.answer: A Fargo soundtrack, including scene descriptions, can be found on Tunefind.

items.question: Are there any reoccurring characters for each season?
items.answer: Lou Solverson: Ex-cop turned diner owner in Season One, in Season Two, the prequel, he was a state trooper.Mr. Wrench: The Deaf hitman in Season One who was seen escaping a hospital bed while guarded by police, only to be in a prison transport with Nikki Swango in Season Three. He is seen as a young child playing baseball with his friend and future partner-in-crime Mr. Numbers at the end of Season Two.Mr. Numbers: Mr. Wrench's friend and partner who serves as a hitman for the Fargo syndicate in Season One. He appears as a young child, playing catch with a young Wrench, at the end of Season Two.Mike Milligan: The African-American Crime Boss from Season Two, his original name is Satchel Cannon, son of crime boss Loy Cannon, after his father died he changed his name to Mike Milligan, took the last name of the man who saved his life.Gale Kitchen: One of the Jewish twin enforcers from Season Two. Seen at the end of Season Four driving Mike Milligan.The characters of Molly Solverson, Gus Grimly, and Greta Grimly briefly appear in a flash forward at the end of Season Two. Season One actors Martin Freeman and Billy Bob Thornton narrate episodes from Seasons Two and Three respectively.

spoilerItems.question: Given the ruckus narrated during the whole season 2 (i.e. the assassination of a city judge in another state, several shootings involving organized crime members from the whole Midwest, and an alleged drug and gun-running interstate operation, etc), how could a federal prosecutor, or any federal law agency for that matter, not be concerned by, at least, one of these cases? And wouldn't be more efficient to sue every party within a federal jurisdiction?Also, what exactly falls into a state policeman's authority when investigating in another state?
How does this series relate to Fargo (1996)?
spoilerItems.answer: In the movie , Carl Showalter buries the case of money in some snow by a barbwire fence. In the Fargo (2014), it is shown in a flashback that Stavros Milos discovers the case of money.Both the series and the movie take place in the state of Minnesota. The characters and themes are similar, in which the small town Midwest culture to keeping things calm and status quo, and wrapping things up nicely clashes when some other city forces arrive. Also, similar to the Coen brothers writing (and somewhat like Tarantino writing), many of the character have a strong sense of morals and principles which leads to conflicts over small details. There are also intricate storytelling, monologues and parables similar to these directors' movie style. Edit

spoilerItems.question: Season 1: Why did Lester confront Malvo in the elevator?
spoilerItems.answer: Successfully managing to escape prosecution for the murder of his wife gave Lester a new outlook on life after years of being emasculated by everyone he knew. After shifting the blame to his more successful and passive aggressive brother, Lester's life changed dramatically: marrying a trophy wife, moving to a large and expensive house and starting his own insurance agency. Lester was convinced that he was invincible after an entire life of failure, so when he spotted Malvo for the first time in a year, Lester no longer feared him and somewhat thought that Malvo was the catalyst for his turnaround. Lester either wanted to thank Malvo or confront him (believing that he was finally strong enough), but unfortunately he chose to do so at a time that compromised an important job that Malvo had been working on for six months.
